reviewText: Claude Rains!!  Wow!  The only actor to EVER successfully upstage Bette Davis in a scene!  He could do anything!  I truly miss him.  A great actor...

Claude Raines was a great actor probably known most for his
role as the father in The Wolfman! but I think this is his
best movie. I can't believe nobody commented on this. I've
had this on vhs for years watched twice. I just finished
watching it again and it's still great. The story about a
fake fortune teller who becomes a clairvoyant by predicting
a train wreck. He then goes on to predict another disaster
and is put on trail for causing accident. Fay Wray plays his
wife and fantastic and beautiful as always. This is a must
for old mystery/horror fans with great story and acting!

First, let me say that I saw this movie on TCM a while back and fell in love with it.  Hoping to add it my collection one day, I was stunned to see it while browsing through this site.  My disappointment came when I began to view it and realized that something was missing.  There is an opening steamship sequence that lasts about 8 minutes that is missing from this print.  Hopefully the british copy will surface on DVD one day soon.  The packaging claims that the movie is 90 minutes long...I think originally it was around 83, but this print is closer to 69.  If you are a Rains or Wray fan, then it is better than nothing.  If you are a completist I would skip this print.

This film is great. It has Claude Rains (Casablanca (Two-Disc Special Edition),Invisible Man - The Legacy Collection (The Invisible Man/Invisible Man Returns/Invisible Agent/Invisible Woman/Invisible Man's Revenge) and Notorious - Criterion Collection) and fay Wray(King Kong (Two-Disc Special Edition),Doctor X (1932) & the Return of Doctor X (1939) - Authentic Region 1 DVD From Warner Brothers Starring Humphrey Bogart, Lionel Atwill, Fay Wray, Lee Tracy, Preston S Foster, Rosemary Lane, Dennis Morgan, John Litel, Huntz Hall & Directed By Michael Curt...,The Mystery of the Wax Museum / 1933 / Fay Wray)and was made in 1934. This film is very good, but for your information, the quality of the print is lacking. It is, however watchable.

I saw this movie listed on Prime and thought why not watch it? I loved it. Good storyline and acting.

I've came up with my own character in this film, but my story is a sequel to this film. Go Maximus! Go Claude! Didn't like Christine Shawn, I knew she was up to something, like trying to steal Maximus from Rene. I love this version of the film.
Huge fan of claude raines. But the left me with blank maybe I'll watch it again to see if i missed something.
It is Claude Rains.  There is nothing else to day

A good movie but is in bad need of restoration.  The poor quality of both audio and video made it too hard to watch and hear.  I gave up after 20 or 30 minutes.  Streaming in standard definition didn't help matters either.

All the movies I've seen with Claude Rains are excellent.  However, the title is deceiving - his gift of being able to see the future isn't evil.  I'd prefer they stick with the original title, The Clairvoyant.
Couldn't get through this movie. The sound is TERRIBLE and the picture is DARK!!!

Maximus (Claude Raines- THE INVISIBLE MAN, THE WOLF MAN) is a performing "mind-reader". Along w/ his wife / assistant, Rene (Fay Wray- DOCTOR X, THE MOST DANGEROUS GAME, THE VAMPIRE BAT, MYSTERY OF THE WAX MUSEUM, KING KONG) he tells people what objects they're holding, while blind-folded. Of course, it's all just an act. One night, a bizarre incident occurs, causing Maximus to actually present evidence of real telepathic ability! After predicting and preventing a train wreck, Max decides to cash in on his new-found psychic powers, demanding a huge pay increase. Then, he makes a prediction on a horse race, calling a 100-1 horse as the winner! Not surprisingly, this all goes to Maximus' head, causing great strain on his marriage. Tragedy soon strikes, and the truth is revealed about the source of Maximus' power. THE EVIL MIND is a suitably melodramatic, supernatural thriller. Raines and Wray are splendid in their roles. Entertaining and different...
